<figure class="wp-block-image size-full avatarBlog"><img width="145" height="145" src="http://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/Blog.jpg" alt="" class="wp-image-33"/></figure>


<div class="BlogTitleClass wp-block-post-date"><time datetime="2021-02-01T11:18:00+00:00">1 February 2021</time></div>

<figure class="BlogImageClass wp-block-post-featured-image"><img width="2560" height="967" src="https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/2021_02_01_rel-scaled.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="Example of a relation expressed in a sentence: &quot;IL-4 induction of GATA3&quot; is a &quot;Positive regulation&quot; with IL-4 and GATA3 both annotates as &quot;GGP&quot;, which stands for &quot;Gene or Gene Product&quot;" style="object-fit:cover;" decoding="async" fetchpriority="high" srcset="https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/2021_02_01_rel-scaled.jpg 2560w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/2021_02_01_rel-300x113.jpg 300w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/2021_02_01_rel-1024x387.jpg 1024w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/2021_02_01_rel-768x290.jpg 768w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/2021_02_01_rel-1536x580.jpg 1536w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/2021_02_01_rel-2048x773.jpg 2048w" sizes="(max-width: 2560px) 100vw, 2560px" /></figure>

<h2 class="has-text-align-center wp-block-post-title">Implementing a custom trainable component for relation extraction</h2></div>


<div class="entry-content BlogTextClass wp-block-post-content has-global-padding is-layout-constrained wp-block-post-content-is-layout-constrained"><p><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8HL-Ap5_Axo&amp;ab_channel=Explosion" target="_blank" rel="noopener">This video</a> shows how to apply the new spaCy v3 features as we work our way through implementing a new custom component from scratch. We <a href="https://github.com/explosion/projects/tree/v3/tutorials/rel_component" target="_blank" rel="noopener">build</a> a machine learning model in Thinc, implement a new spaCy component, train it with the new configuration system and demonstrate how to use a pre-trained transformer model from the Hugging Face Transformers library to boost your performance.</p>
<p>The specific challenge we are setting ourselves here is implementing a custom component to predict relationships between named entities, also called relation extraction. In the most basic form, we take two entities previously predicted by a named entity recognizer and try to determine whether there is a semantic relationship between them and, if so, label it.</p>
<p>In this video, I focus on predicting biomedical relations between genes and proteins. Biomedical NLP is a research area that I am passionate about, and I’ve worked in this domain extensively during my PhD and postdoc, now many years ago. For demonstration purposes, I’ve simplified the challenge and the annotation format quite a bit.</p>
<p>You can adapt this approach to predict any type of relations between any type of entities. The performance of your relation extraction module will depend on the specific challenge and dataset, but keep in mind that predicting relations from text is a difficult task overall.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><b>→ Authors: </b>Sofie Van Landeghem, Ines Montani</p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><b>→ Video: </b><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8HL-Ap5_Axo&amp;ab_channel=Explosion" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Youtube</a></p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><b>→  Code</b>: <a href="https://github.com/explosion/projects/tree/v3/tutorials/rel_component" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Github</a></p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><b>→  Transcription</b>: <a href="https://explosion.ai/blog/relation-extraction" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Blog post</a></p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</section>

		<script>
			const tl = gsap.timeline({
				scrollTrigger: {
					trigger: "#hero",
					start: "top top",
					end: "bottom top",
					scrub: true
				}
			});

			gsap.utils.toArray(".parallax").forEach(layer => {
				const depth = layer.dataset.depth;
				const movement = -(layer.offsetHeight * depth)
				tl.to(layer, {y: movement, ease: "none"}, 0)
			});
		</script>
		
		<script>
			/* When the user scrolls down, hide the navbar. When the user scrolls up, show the navbar */
			var prevScrollpos = window.pageYOffset;
			window.onscroll = function() {
				var currentScrollPos = window.pageYOffset;								
				
				var x = window.matchMedia("(min-width: 1851px)")
				if(x.matches) {
					if(currentScrollPos > 0) {						
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 0}, 1000);*/

					}
					if(currentScrollPos <= 0) {
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 1}, 1000);*/
					}
				}
				else{
					if(currentScrollPos > 0) {						
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 0}, 1000);*/
					}
					if(currentScrollPos <= 0) {
					/* 	document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 1}, 1000);*/
					}
				}
			
				if(currentScrollPos == "0.0") {
					document.getElementById("nav").style.top = "0.5em";
					<!-- document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = 'auto'; -->
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.borderRadius = '0.8em';
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = "auto";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.width = "40em";
				}
				if (prevScrollpos > currentScrollPos) {
					
				} else {					
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.cssText += 'height:auto;';
					document.getElementById("nav").style.top = "-1.0em";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.borderRadius = '0em';
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = "2.5em";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.width = "100%";					
				}
				prevScrollpos = currentScrollPos;
			}
		</script></footer></main>

<script id="wp-block-template-skip-link-js-after">
	( function() {
		var skipLinkTarget = document.querySelector( 'main' ),
			sibling,
			skipLinkTargetID,
			skipLink;

		// Early exit if a skip-link target can't be located.
		if ( ! skipLinkTarget ) {
			return;
		}

		/*
		 * Get the site wrapper.
		 * The skip-link will be injected in the beginning of it.
		 */
		sibling = document.querySelector( '.wp-site-blocks' );

		// Early exit if the root element was not found.
		if ( ! sibling ) {
			return;
		}

		// Get the skip-link target's ID, and generate one if it doesn't exist.
		skipLinkTargetID = skipLinkTarget.id;
		if ( ! skipLinkTargetID ) {
			skipLinkTargetID = 'wp--skip-link--target';
			skipLinkTarget.id = skipLinkTargetID;
		}

		// Create the skip link.
		skipLink = document.createElement( 'a' );
		skipLink.classList.add( 'skip-link', 'screen-reader-text' );
		skipLink.id = 'wp-skip-link';
		skipLink.href = '#' + skipLinkTargetID;
		skipLink.innerText = 'Skip to content';

		// Inject the skip link.
		sibling.parentElement.insertBefore( skipLink, sibling );
	}() );
	
</script>

 <section id="Blog" class="Blog" style="Padding: 0 0 0 0">
<div class="container">															



<main class="wp-block-group is-layout-flow wp-block-group-is-layout-flow">
<div class="wp-block-group has-global-padding is-layout-constrained wp-block-group-is-layout-constrained">
<div style="height:var(--wp--preset--spacing--50)" aria-hidden="true" class="wp-block-spacer"></div>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-full avatarBlog"><img width="145" height="145" src="http://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/Blog.jpg" alt="" class="wp-image-33"/></figure>


<div class="BlogTitleClass wp-block-post-date"><time datetime="2020-02-19T14:15:00+00:00">19 February 2020</time></div>

<figure class="BlogImageClass wp-block-post-featured-image"><img width="2910" height="1286" src="https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2020_02_19_turku.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="A diagram showing how a spaCy pipeline consists of several components running in sequence: e.g. first a tagger, then a parser, then NER." style="object-fit:cover;" decoding="async" fetchpriority="high" srcset="https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2020_02_19_turku.png 2910w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2020_02_19_turku-300x133.png 300w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2020_02_19_turku-1024x453.png 1024w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2020_02_19_turku-768x339.png 768w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2020_02_19_turku-1536x679.png 1536w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2020_02_19_turku-2048x905.png 2048w" sizes="(max-width: 2910px) 100vw, 2910px" /></figure>

<h2 class="has-text-align-center wp-block-post-title">Building customizable NLP pipelines with spaCy</h2></div>


<div class="entry-content BlogTextClass wp-block-post-content has-global-padding is-layout-constrained wp-block-post-content-is-layout-constrained"><p>spaCy is an industrial-strength Natural Language Processing library which allows you to quickly build performant pipelines to tackle specific NLP challenges. It comes with pretrained Machine Learning models for 10 languages and has basic support for over 50 languages. In this talk, I showcase the usage of spaCy as well as give a peak preview on the upcoming spaCy v.3 which will give the user full control over the model internals via configuration files.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><b>→  Venue</b>: Turku.AI Meetup (Turku, Finland)</p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><b>→  Slides</b>: <a href="https://speakerdeck.com/sofievl/2020-02-19-spacy-pipelines" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Speakerdeck</a></p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</section>
</section>

		<script>
			const tl = gsap.timeline({
				scrollTrigger: {
					trigger: "#hero",
					start: "top top",
					end: "bottom top",
					scrub: true
				}
			});

			gsap.utils.toArray(".parallax").forEach(layer => {
				const depth = layer.dataset.depth;
				const movement = -(layer.offsetHeight * depth)
				tl.to(layer, {y: movement, ease: "none"}, 0)
			});
		</script>
		
		<script>
			/* When the user scrolls down, hide the navbar. When the user scrolls up, show the navbar */
			var prevScrollpos = window.pageYOffset;
			window.onscroll = function() {
				var currentScrollPos = window.pageYOffset;								
				
				var x = window.matchMedia("(min-width: 1851px)")
				if(x.matches) {
					if(currentScrollPos > 0) {						
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 0}, 1000);*/

					}
					if(currentScrollPos <= 0) {
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 1}, 1000);*/
					}
				}
				else{
					if(currentScrollPos > 0) {						
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 0}, 1000);*/
					}
					if(currentScrollPos <= 0) {
					/* 	document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 1}, 1000);*/
					}
				}
			
				if(currentScrollPos == "0.0") {
					document.getElementById("nav").style.top = "0.5em";
					<!-- document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = 'auto'; -->
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.borderRadius = '0.8em';
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = "auto";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.width = "40em";
				}
				if (prevScrollpos > currentScrollPos) {
					
				} else {					
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.cssText += 'height:auto;';
					document.getElementById("nav").style.top = "-1.0em";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.borderRadius = '0em';
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = "2.5em";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.width = "100%";					
				}
				prevScrollpos = currentScrollPos;
			}
		</script></footer></main>

{"prefetch":[{"source":"document","where":{"and":[{"href_matches":"\/*"},{"not":{"href_matches":["\/wp-*.php","\/wp-admin\/*","\/wp-content\/uploads\/*","\/wp-content\/*","\/wp-content\/plugins\/*","\/wp-content\/themes\/twentytwentyfour\/*","\/*\\?(.+)"]}},{"not":{"selector_matches":"a[rel~=\"nofollow\"]"}},{"not":{"selector_matches":".no-prefetch, .no-prefetch a"}}]},"eagerness":"conservative"}]}

<script id="wp-block-template-skip-link-js-after">
	( function() {
		var skipLinkTarget = document.querySelector( 'main' ),
			sibling,
			skipLinkTargetID,
			skipLink;

		// Early exit if a skip-link target can't be located.
		if ( ! skipLinkTarget ) {
			return;
		}

		/*
		 * Get the site wrapper.
		 * The skip-link will be injected in the beginning of it.
		 */
		sibling = document.querySelector( '.wp-site-blocks' );

		// Early exit if the root element was not found.
		if ( ! sibling ) {
			return;
		}

		// Get the skip-link target's ID, and generate one if it doesn't exist.
		skipLinkTargetID = skipLinkTarget.id;
		if ( ! skipLinkTargetID ) {
			skipLinkTargetID = 'wp--skip-link--target';
			skipLinkTarget.id = skipLinkTargetID;
		}

		// Create the skip link.
		skipLink = document.createElement( 'a' );
		skipLink.classList.add( 'skip-link', 'screen-reader-text' );
		skipLink.id = 'wp-skip-link';
		skipLink.href = '#' + skipLinkTargetID;
		skipLink.innerText = 'Skip to content';

		// Inject the skip link.
		sibling.parentElement.insertBefore( skipLink, sibling );
	}() );
	
</script>
</body>

<div class="BlogTitleClass wp-block-post-date"><time datetime="2019-10-01T14:35:00+00:00">1 October 2019</time></div>

<figure class="BlogImageClass wp-block-post-featured-image"><img width="2932" height="606" src="https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2019_10_01_el.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="Flowchart showing the required steps in the pipeline: First NER, then candidate generation, then Entity Linking (EL)" style="object-fit:cover;" decoding="async" fetchpriority="high" srcset="https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2019_10_01_el.png 2932w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2019_10_01_el-300x62.png 300w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2019_10_01_el-1024x212.png 1024w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2019_10_01_el-768x159.png 768w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2019_10_01_el-1536x317.png 1536w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2019_10_01_el-2048x423.png 2048w" sizes="(max-width: 2932px) 100vw, 2932px" /></figure>

<h2 class="has-text-align-center wp-block-post-title">Entity linking for spaCy: Grounding textual mentions</h2></div>


<div class="entry-content BlogTextClass wp-block-post-content has-global-padding is-layout-constrained wp-block-post-content-is-layout-constrained"><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Up until recently, spaCy&#8217;s functionality was limited to the actual text in the sentences, defining words only in the context of other words. In this talk, I present my recent work on adding Entity Linking functionality to spaCy, which allows grounding information from text into &#8220;real world&#8221; unique identifiers defined by a knowledge base (KB). This normalization step allows to integrate textual information with structured data in downstream tasks. My talk walks you through the challenges and potential solutions of this disambiguation task, including the implementation of an in-memory KB which is fast and efficient, and a flexible neural network architecture that encodes both the entity information as well as the sentence context.</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><b>→  Venue</b>: <span style="font-weight: 400;">Belgian NLP meetup</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><b>→  Slides</b>: <a href="https://speakerdeck.com/sofievl/2019-10-01-el-spacy" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Speakerdeck</a></p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</section>
</section>

		<script>
			const tl = gsap.timeline({
				scrollTrigger: {
					trigger: "#hero",
					start: "top top",
					end: "bottom top",
					scrub: true
				}
			});

			gsap.utils.toArray(".parallax").forEach(layer => {
				const depth = layer.dataset.depth;
				const movement = -(layer.offsetHeight * depth)
				tl.to(layer, {y: movement, ease: "none"}, 0)
			});
		</script>
		
		<script>
			/* When the user scrolls down, hide the navbar. When the user scrolls up, show the navbar */
			var prevScrollpos = window.pageYOffset;
			window.onscroll = function() {
				var currentScrollPos = window.pageYOffset;								
				
				var x = window.matchMedia("(min-width: 1851px)")
				if(x.matches) {
					if(currentScrollPos > 0) {						
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 0}, 1000);*/

					}
					if(currentScrollPos <= 0) {
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 1}, 1000);*/
					}
				}
				else{
					if(currentScrollPos > 0) {						
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 0}, 1000);*/
					}
					if(currentScrollPos <= 0) {
					/* 	document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 1}, 1000);*/
					}
				}
			
				if(currentScrollPos == "0.0") {
					document.getElementById("nav").style.top = "0.5em";
					<!-- document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = 'auto'; -->
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.borderRadius = '0.8em';
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = "auto";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.width = "40em";
				}
				if (prevScrollpos > currentScrollPos) {
					
				} else {					
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.cssText += 'height:auto;';
					document.getElementById("nav").style.top = "-1.0em";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.borderRadius = '0em';
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = "2.5em";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.width = "100%";					
				}
				prevScrollpos = currentScrollPos;
			}
		</script></footer></main>

{"prefetch":[{"source":"document","where":{"and":[{"href_matches":"\/*"},{"not":{"href_matches":["\/wp-*.php","\/wp-admin\/*","\/wp-content\/uploads\/*","\/wp-content\/*","\/wp-content\/plugins\/*","\/wp-content\/themes\/twentytwentyfour\/*","\/*\\?(.+)"]}},{"not":{"selector_matches":"a[rel~=\"nofollow\"]"}},{"not":{"selector_matches":".no-prefetch, .no-prefetch a"}}]},"eagerness":"conservative"}]}

<script id="wp-block-template-skip-link-js-after">
	( function() {
		var skipLinkTarget = document.querySelector( 'main' ),
			sibling,
			skipLinkTargetID,
			skipLink;

		// Early exit if a skip-link target can't be located.
		if ( ! skipLinkTarget ) {
			return;
		}

		/*
		 * Get the site wrapper.
		 * The skip-link will be injected in the beginning of it.
		 */
		sibling = document.querySelector( '.wp-site-blocks' );

		// Early exit if the root element was not found.
		if ( ! sibling ) {
			return;
		}

		// Get the skip-link target's ID, and generate one if it doesn't exist.
		skipLinkTargetID = skipLinkTarget.id;
		if ( ! skipLinkTargetID ) {
			skipLinkTargetID = 'wp--skip-link--target';
			skipLinkTarget.id = skipLinkTargetID;
		}

		// Create the skip link.
		skipLink = document.createElement( 'a' );
		skipLink.classList.add( 'skip-link', 'screen-reader-text' );
		skipLink.id = 'wp-skip-link';
		skipLink.href = '#' + skipLinkTargetID;
		skipLink.innerText = 'Skip to content';

		// Inject the skip link.
		sibling.parentElement.insertBefore( skipLink, sibling );
	}() );
	
</script>

e)n.supports[t]=e[t],n.supports.everything=n.supports.everything&&n.supports[t],"flag"!==t&&(n.supports.everythingExceptFlag=n.supports.everythingExceptFlag&&n.supports[t]);n.supports.everythingExceptFlag=n.supports.everythingExceptFlag&&!n.supports.flag,n.DOMReady=!1,n.readyCallback=function(){n.DOMReady=!0}}).then(function(){return e}).then(function(){var </script>

<figure class="BlogImageClass wp-block-post-featured-image"><img width="2069" height="1500" src="https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2019_07_12_spacy_IRL_2.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="Picture of Sofie giving the presentation" style="object-fit:cover;" decoding="async" fetchpriority="high" srcset="https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2019_07_12_spacy_IRL_2.jpg 2069w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2019_07_12_spacy_IRL_2-300x217.jpg 300w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2019_07_12_spacy_IRL_2-1024x742.jpg 1024w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2019_07_12_spacy_IRL_2-768x557.jpg 768w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2019_07_12_spacy_IRL_2-1536x1114.jpg 1536w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2019_07_12_spacy_IRL_2-2048x1485.jpg 2048w" sizes="(max-width: 2069px) 100vw, 2069px" /></figure>

<h2 class="has-text-align-center wp-block-post-title">Entity linking functionality in spaCy</h2></div>


<div class="entry-content BlogTextClass wp-block-post-content has-global-padding is-layout-constrained wp-block-post-content-is-layout-constrained"><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Up until recently, spaCy&#8217;s functionality was limited to the actual text in the sentences, defining words only in the context of other words. In this talk, I present my recent work on adding Entity Linking functionality to spaCy, which allows grounding information from text into &#8220;real world&#8221; unique identifiers defined by a knowledge base (KB). This normalization step allows to integrate textual information with structured data in downstream tasks. My talk walks you through the challenges and potential solutions of this disambiguation task, including the implementation of an in-memory KB which is fast and efficient, and a flexible neural network architecture that encodes both the entity information as well as the sentence context.</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><b>→  Venue</b>: spaCy IRL 2019 (Berlin, Germany)</p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><b>→ Video: </b><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PW3RJM8tDGo&amp;list=PLBmcuObd5An4UC6jvK_-eSl6jCvP1gwXc&amp;index=7" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Youtube</a><b><br />
</b></p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><b>→ </b><strong>Blost post:</strong> <a href="https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/entity-linking-spacy-sofie-van-landeghem" target="_blank" rel="noopener">LinkedIn</a></p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><b>→  Slides</b>: <a href="https://speakerdeck.com/sofievl/2019-07-12-irl" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Speakerdeck</a></p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</section>
</section>

		<script>
			const tl = gsap.timeline({
				scrollTrigger: {
					trigger: "#hero",
					start: "top top",
					end: "bottom top",
					scrub: true
				}
			});

			gsap.utils.toArray(".parallax").forEach(layer => {
				const depth = layer.dataset.depth;
				const movement = -(layer.offsetHeight * depth)
				tl.to(layer, {y: movement, ease: "none"}, 0)
			});
		</script>
		
		<script>
			/* When the user scrolls down, hide the navbar. When the user scrolls up, show the navbar */
			var prevScrollpos = window.pageYOffset;
			window.onscroll = function() {
				var currentScrollPos = window.pageYOffset;								
				
				var x = window.matchMedia("(min-width: 1851px)")
				if(x.matches) {
					if(currentScrollPos > 0) {						
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 0}, 1000);*/

					}
					if(currentScrollPos <= 0) {
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 1}, 1000);*/
					}
				}
				else{
					if(currentScrollPos > 0) {						
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 0}, 1000);*/
					}
					if(currentScrollPos <= 0) {
					/* 	document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 1}, 1000);*/
					}
				}
			
				if(currentScrollPos == "0.0") {
					document.getElementById("nav").style.top = "0.5em";
					<!-- document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = 'auto'; -->
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.borderRadius = '0.8em';
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = "auto";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.width = "40em";
				}
				if (prevScrollpos > currentScrollPos) {
					
				} else {					
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.cssText += 'height:auto;';
					document.getElementById("nav").style.top = "-1.0em";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.borderRadius = '0em';
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = "2.5em";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.width = "100%";					
				}
				prevScrollpos = currentScrollPos;
			}
		</script></footer></main>

<script id="wp-block-template-skip-link-js-after">
	( function() {
		var skipLinkTarget = document.querySelector( 'main' ),
			sibling,
			skipLinkTargetID,
			skipLink;

		// Early exit if a skip-link target can't be located.
		if ( ! skipLinkTarget ) {
			return;
		}

		/*
		 * Get the site wrapper.
		 * The skip-link will be injected in the beginning of it.
		 */
		sibling = document.querySelector( '.wp-site-blocks' );

		// Early exit if the root element was not found.
		if ( ! sibling ) {
			return;
		}

		// Get the skip-link target's ID, and generate one if it doesn't exist.
		skipLinkTargetID = skipLinkTarget.id;
		if ( ! skipLinkTargetID ) {
			skipLinkTargetID = 'wp--skip-link--target';
			skipLinkTarget.id = skipLinkTargetID;
		}

		// Create the skip link.
		skipLink = document.createElement( 'a' );
		skipLink.classList.add( 'skip-link', 'screen-reader-text' );
		skipLink.id = 'wp-skip-link';
		skipLink.href = '#' + skipLinkTargetID;
		skipLink.innerText = 'Skip to content';

		// Inject the skip link.
		sibling.parentElement.insertBefore( skipLink, sibling );
	}() );
	
</script>

<style id='wp-block-post-featured-image-inline-css'>

<main class="wp-block-group is-layout-flow wp-block-group-is-layout-flow">
<div class="wp-block-group has-global-padding is-layout-constrained wp-block-group-is-layout-constrained">

<figure class="wp-block-image size-full avatarBlog"><img width="145" height="145" src="http://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/Blog.jpg" alt="" class="wp-image-33"/></figure>


<div class="BlogTitleClass wp-block-post-date"><time datetime="2019-02-27T14:44:00+00:00">27 February 2019</time></div>

<figure class="BlogImageClass wp-block-post-featured-image"><img width="3158" height="1647" src="https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2019_02_27_diffany.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="Picture showing a differential network" style="object-fit:cover;" decoding="async" fetchpriority="high" srcset="https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2019_02_27_diffany.png 3158w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2019_02_27_diffany-300x156.png 300w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2019_02_27_diffany-1024x534.png 1024w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2019_02_27_diffany-768x401.png 768w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2019_02_27_diffany-1536x801.png 1536w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2019_02_27_diffany-2048x1068.png 2048w" sizes="(max-width: 3158px) 100vw, 3158px" /></figure>

<h2 class="has-text-align-center wp-block-post-title">Studying the dynamic rewiring of molecular networks </h2></div>


<div class="entry-content BlogTextClass wp-block-post-content has-global-padding is-layout-constrained wp-block-post-content-is-layout-constrained"><p>In this talk, I showcase how methods from Natural Language Processing, Data Integration and Graph Analysis all contribute to studying the dynamic rewiring of molecular networks. I first explain some basic concepts from Text mining and show how they can ultimately be used to perform pathway reconstruction from literature, or how to mine clinical trials for structured information. Further, I illustrate the need for data integration, and apply differential network analyses on a plant osmotic stress use-case. The analysis ultimately revealed 3 novel genes for further experiments, and the results were published in BMC Bioinformatics.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><b>→  Venue</b>: Women in Tech &#8211; Belgium</p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><b>→  Slides</b>: <a href="https://speakerdeck.com/sofievl/2019-02-27-network-rewiring" target="_blank" rel="noopener">SpeakerDeck</a></p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><b>→  Original paper</b>: <a href="https://bmcbioinformatics.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s12859-015-0863-y" target="_blank" rel="noopener">BMC Bioinformatics</a></p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</section>
</section>

		<script src="https://s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s.cdpn.io/16327/gsap-latest-beta.min.js?r=5426"></script>
		<script src="https://s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s.cdpn.io/16327/ScrollTrigger.min.js"></script>
		<script src="https://frogcat.github.io/canvas-arrow/canvas-arrow.js"></script>
		
		<script>
			const tl = gsap.timeline({
				scrollTrigger: {
					trigger: "#hero",
					start: "top top",
					end: "bottom top",
					scrub: true
				}
			});

			gsap.utils.toArray(".parallax").forEach(layer => {
				const depth = layer.dataset.depth;
				const movement = -(layer.offsetHeight * depth)
				tl.to(layer, {y: movement, ease: "none"}, 0)
			});
		</script>
		
		<script>
			/* When the user scrolls down, hide the navbar. When the user scrolls up, show the navbar */
			var prevScrollpos = window.pageYOffset;
			window.onscroll = function() {
				var currentScrollPos = window.pageYOffset;								
				
				var x = window.matchMedia("(min-width: 1851px)")
				if(x.matches) {
					if(currentScrollPos > 0) {						
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 0}, 1000);*/

					}
					if(currentScrollPos <= 0) {
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 1}, 1000);*/
					}
				}
				else{
					if(currentScrollPos > 0) {						
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 0}, 1000);*/
					}
					if(currentScrollPos <= 0) {
					/* 	document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 1}, 1000);*/
					}
				}
			
				if(currentScrollPos == "0.0") {
					document.getElementById("nav").style.top = "0.5em";
					<!-- document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = 'auto'; -->
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.borderRadius = '0.8em';
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = "auto";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.width = "40em";
				}
				if (prevScrollpos > currentScrollPos) {
					
				} else {					
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.cssText += 'height:auto;';
					document.getElementById("nav").style.top = "-1.0em";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.borderRadius = '0em';
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = "2.5em";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.width = "100%";					
				}
				prevScrollpos = currentScrollPos;
			}
		</script></footer></main>
</div>
<script type="speculationrules">
{"prefetch":[{"source":"document","where":{"and":[{"href_matches":"\/*"},{"not":{"href_matches":["\/wp-*.php","\/wp-admin\/*","\/wp-content\/uploads\/*","\/wp-content\/*","\/wp-content\/plugins\/*","\/wp-content\/themes\/twentytwentyfour\/*","\/*\\?(.+)"]}},{"not":{"selector_matches":"a[rel~=\"nofollow\"]"}},{"not":{"selector_matches":".no-prefetch, .no-prefetch a"}}]},"eagerness":"conservative"}]}

<script id="wp-block-template-skip-link-js-after">
	( function() {
		var skipLinkTarget = document.querySelector( 'main' ),
			sibling,
			skipLinkTargetID,
			skipLink;

		// Early exit if a skip-link target can't be located.
		if ( ! skipLinkTarget ) {
			return;
		}

		/*
		 * Get the site wrapper.
		 * The skip-link will be injected in the beginning of it.
		 */
		sibling = document.querySelector( '.wp-site-blocks' );

		// Early exit if the root element was not found.
		if ( ! sibling ) {
			return;
		}

		// Get the skip-link target's ID, and generate one if it doesn't exist.
		skipLinkTargetID = skipLinkTarget.id;
		if ( ! skipLinkTargetID ) {
			skipLinkTargetID = 'wp--skip-link--target';
			skipLinkTarget.id = skipLinkTargetID;
		}

		// Create the skip link.
		skipLink = document.createElement( 'a' );
		skipLink.classList.add( 'skip-link', 'screen-reader-text' );
		skipLink.id = 'wp-skip-link';
		skipLink.href = '#' + skipLinkTargetID;
		skipLink.innerText = 'Skip to content';

		// Inject the skip link.
		sibling.parentElement.insertBefore( skipLink, sibling );
	}() );
	
</script>
</body>

			background-color: #eee;
			clip-path: none;

<div class="BlogTitleClass wp-block-post-date"><time datetime="2019-02-01T14:48:00+00:00">1 February 2019</time></div>

<figure class="BlogImageClass wp-block-post-featured-image"><img width="819" height="552" src="https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2019_02_01_tokenization_speed.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="Graph showing the speed of models before and after this PR, showing the boost in speed of this contribution." style="object-fit:cover;" decoding="async" fetchpriority="high" srcset="https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2019_02_01_tokenization_speed.png 819w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2019_02_01_tokenization_speed-300x202.png 300w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2019_02_01_tokenization_speed-768x518.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 819px) 100vw, 819px" /></figure>

<h2 class="has-text-align-center wp-block-post-title">Increasing tokenization speed across spaCy&#8217;s core languages</h2></div>


<div class="entry-content BlogTextClass wp-block-post-content has-global-padding is-layout-constrained wp-block-post-content-is-layout-constrained"><p>One of my first core contributions to the spaCy open-source NLP library!</p>
<p>This PR increases tokenization speed by 2-3 times across languages at the same accuracy by refactoring the regular expressions and replacing `regex` with `re`.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><b>→  Code</b>: <a href="https://github.com/explosion/spaCy/pull/3218" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Github</a></p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</section>
</section>

		<script>
			const tl = gsap.timeline({
				scrollTrigger: {
					trigger: "#hero",
					start: "top top",
					end: "bottom top",
					scrub: true
				}
			});

			gsap.utils.toArray(".parallax").forEach(layer => {
				const depth = layer.dataset.depth;
				const movement = -(layer.offsetHeight * depth)
				tl.to(layer, {y: movement, ease: "none"}, 0)
			});
		</script>
		
		<script>
			/* When the user scrolls down, hide the navbar. When the user scrolls up, show the navbar */
			var prevScrollpos = window.pageYOffset;
			window.onscroll = function() {
				var currentScrollPos = window.pageYOffset;								
				
				var x = window.matchMedia("(min-width: 1851px)")
				if(x.matches) {
					if(currentScrollPos > 0) {						
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 0}, 1000);*/

					}
					if(currentScrollPos <= 0) {
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 1}, 1000);*/
					}
				}
				else{
					if(currentScrollPos > 0) {						
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 0}, 1000);*/
					}
					if(currentScrollPos <= 0) {
					/* 	document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 1}, 1000);*/
					}
				}
			
				if(currentScrollPos == "0.0") {
					document.getElementById("nav").style.top = "0.5em";
					<!-- document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = 'auto'; -->
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.borderRadius = '0.8em';
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = "auto";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.width = "40em";
				}
				if (prevScrollpos > currentScrollPos) {
					
				} else {					
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.cssText += 'height:auto;';
					document.getElementById("nav").style.top = "-1.0em";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.borderRadius = '0em';
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = "2.5em";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.width = "100%";					
				}
				prevScrollpos = currentScrollPos;
			}
		</script></footer></main>

<script id="wp-block-template-skip-link-js-after">
	( function() {
		var skipLinkTarget = document.querySelector( 'main' ),
			sibling,
			skipLinkTargetID,
			skipLink;

		// Early exit if a skip-link target can't be located.
		if ( ! skipLinkTarget ) {
			return;
		}

		/*
		 * Get the site wrapper.
		 * The skip-link will be injected in the beginning of it.
		 */
		sibling = document.querySelector( '.wp-site-blocks' );

		// Early exit if the root element was not found.
		if ( ! sibling ) {
			return;
		}

		// Get the skip-link target's ID, and generate one if it doesn't exist.
		skipLinkTargetID = skipLinkTarget.id;
		if ( ! skipLinkTargetID ) {
			skipLinkTargetID = 'wp--skip-link--target';
			skipLinkTarget.id = skipLinkTargetID;
		}

		// Create the skip link.
		skipLink = document.createElement( 'a' );
		skipLink.classList.add( 'skip-link', 'screen-reader-text' );
		skipLink.id = 'wp-skip-link';
		skipLink.href = '#' + skipLinkTargetID;
		skipLink.innerText = 'Skip to content';

		// Inject the skip link.
		sibling.parentElement.insertBefore( skipLink, sibling );
	}() );
	
</script>

 <section id="intro" class="intro">
  <div class="title">Sofie’s Blog</div>

 <section id="Blog" class="Blog" style="Padding: 0 0 0 0">
<div class="container">															



<main class="wp-block-group is-layout-flow wp-block-group-is-layout-flow">
<div class="wp-block-group has-global-padding is-layout-constrained wp-block-group-is-layout-constrained">
<div style="height:var(--wp--preset--spacing--50)" aria-hidden="true" class="wp-block-spacer"></div>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-full avatarBlog"><img width="145" height="145" src="http://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/Blog.jpg" alt="" class="wp-image-33"/></figure>


<div class="BlogTitleClass wp-block-post-date"><time datetime="2018-06-27T14:51:00+00:00">27 June 2018</time></div>

<figure class="BlogImageClass wp-block-post-featured-image"><img width="1316" height="863" src="https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2018_06_27_tasting.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="Picture of Sofie and colleagues testing cocktail recipes" style="object-fit:cover;" decoding="async" fetchpriority="high" srcset="https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2018_06_27_tasting.png 1316w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2018_06_27_tasting-300x197.png 300w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2018_06_27_tasting-1024x672.png 1024w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2018_06_27_tasting-768x504.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1316px) 100vw, 1316px" /></figure>

<h2 class="has-text-align-center wp-block-post-title">Developing a cocktail generator that optimizes your drink to your taste</h2></div>


<div class="entry-content BlogTextClass wp-block-post-content has-global-padding is-layout-constrained wp-block-post-content-is-layout-constrained"><p>At Foodpairing, we&#8217;re passionate about flavor. In the past few months, I&#8217;ve been working on a revamped version of our cocktail generator. At its core, this cocktail generator has an optimization algorithm that knows which mixers it has at his disposal, as well as which kind of drink a user would like, and then produces a highly personal and super flavorsome mocktail or cocktail as output.</p>
<p>Of couse &#8211; we can&#8217;t just take the algorithm&#8217;s word for it, so today we organized a tasting/testing session of our algorithm together with Peter Coucquyt (co-founder and chef) and Elisa Gragnani (our resident Flavor Insights Strategist). We recreated in real life the cocktails that our algorithm produced on paper, and critically evaluated whether the levels of bitterness, sweetness, floral-ness etc, were all according to the user&#8217;s expectation. Needless to say it&#8217;s been a pretty fun and delicious afternoon at work! If only all algorithm development &amp; testing were this enjoyable!</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</section>
</section>

					</li>

				</ul>
			</nav>

		<script>
			const tl = gsap.timeline({
				scrollTrigger: {
					trigger: "#hero",
					start: "top top",
					end: "bottom top",
					scrub: true
				}
			});

			gsap.utils.toArray(".parallax").forEach(layer => {
				const depth = layer.dataset.depth;
				const movement = -(layer.offsetHeight * depth)
				tl.to(layer, {y: movement, ease: "none"}, 0)
			});
		</script>
		
		<script>
			/* When the user scrolls down, hide the navbar. When the user scrolls up, show the navbar */
			var prevScrollpos = window.pageYOffset;
			window.onscroll = function() {
				var currentScrollPos = window.pageYOffset;								
				
				var x = window.matchMedia("(min-width: 1851px)")
				if(x.matches) {
					if(currentScrollPos > 0) {						
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 0}, 1000);*/

					}
					if(currentScrollPos <= 0) {
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 1}, 1000);*/
					}
				}
				else{
					if(currentScrollPos > 0) {						
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 0}, 1000);*/
					}
					if(currentScrollPos <= 0) {
					/* 	document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 1}, 1000);*/
					}
				}
			
				if(currentScrollPos == "0.0") {
					document.getElementById("nav").style.top = "0.5em";
					<!-- document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = 'auto'; -->
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.borderRadius = '0.8em';
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = "auto";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.width = "40em";
				}
				if (prevScrollpos > currentScrollPos) {
					
				} else {					
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.cssText += 'height:auto;';
					document.getElementById("nav").style.top = "-1.0em";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.borderRadius = '0em';
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = "2.5em";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.width = "100%";					
				}
				prevScrollpos = currentScrollPos;
			}
		</script></footer></main>

<script type="speculationrules">
{"prefetch":[{"source":"document","where":{"and":[{"href_matches":"\/*"},{"not":{"href_matches":["\/wp-*.php","\/wp-admin\/*","\/wp-content\/uploads\/*","\/wp-content\/*","\/wp-content\/plugins\/*","\/wp-content\/themes\/twentytwentyfour\/*","\/*\\?(.+)"]}},{"not":{"selector_matches":"a[rel~=\"nofollow\"]"}},{"not":{"selector_matches":".no-prefetch, .no-prefetch a"}}]},"eagerness":"conservative"}]}

<script id="wp-block-template-skip-link-js-after">
	( function() {
		var skipLinkTarget = document.querySelector( 'main' ),
			sibling,
			skipLinkTargetID,
			skipLink;

		// Early exit if a skip-link target can't be located.
		if ( ! skipLinkTarget ) {
			return;
		}

		/*
		 * Get the site wrapper.
		 * The skip-link will be injected in the beginning of it.
		 */
		sibling = document.querySelector( '.wp-site-blocks' );

		// Early exit if the root element was not found.
		if ( ! sibling ) {
			return;
		}

		// Get the skip-link target's ID, and generate one if it doesn't exist.
		skipLinkTargetID = skipLinkTarget.id;
		if ( ! skipLinkTargetID ) {
			skipLinkTargetID = 'wp--skip-link--target';
			skipLinkTarget.id = skipLinkTargetID;
		}

		// Create the skip link.
		skipLink = document.createElement( 'a' );
		skipLink.classList.add( 'skip-link', 'screen-reader-text' );
		skipLink.id = 'wp-skip-link';
		skipLink.href = '#' + skipLinkTargetID;
		skipLink.innerText = 'Skip to content';

		// Inject the skip link.
		sibling.parentElement.insertBefore( skipLink, sibling );
	}() );
	
</script>
</body>

<div class="BlogTitleClass wp-block-post-date"><time datetime="2016-10-01T15:01:00+00:00">1 October 2016</time></div>

<figure class="BlogImageClass wp-block-post-featured-image"><img width="1600" height="1065" src="https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2016_10_tedxjnj.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="Picture of Sofie giving the talk on the TEDx J&amp;J stage." style="object-fit:cover;" decoding="async" fetchpriority="high" srcset="https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2016_10_tedxjnj.jpg 1600w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2016_10_tedxjnj-300x200.jpg 300w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2016_10_tedxjnj-1024x682.jpg 1024w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2016_10_tedxjnj-768x511.jpg 768w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2016_10_tedxjnj-1536x1022.jpg 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1600px) 100vw, 1600px" /></figure>

<h2 class="has-text-align-center wp-block-post-title">TEDxBigData: Machine Learning &amp; Natural Language Processing</h2></div>


<div class="entry-content BlogTextClass wp-block-post-content has-global-padding is-layout-constrained wp-block-post-content-is-layout-constrained"><p>I had the opportunity to present a TEDx talk to an interested audience at a TEDxBigData event organized by J&amp;J. Being part of the Data Sciences team at Janssen Pharmaceuticals, we constantly strive to identify novel opportunities to enable data-driven decisions throughout the pharmaceutical value chain, by designing and implementing machine learning models.</p>
<p>In this talk, I explained the technology behind Machine Learning by drawing a parallel to how little kids learn their mother tongue: by example. I further illustrated this with Josh Tenenbaum&#8217;s &#8216;Tufa&#8217; example &#8211; allowing the audiene to recognize what is a tufa and what isn&#8217;t in less than a minute &#8211; even if they had never heard of the concept before.</p>
<p>I shared my enthousiasm and love for Natural Language Processing by giving some examples on the complexities and ambiguities in natural language, as well as showing some amazing examples of what NLP can do in concrete business cases today.</p>
<p>While I can&#8217;t share the recording of this talk online, it was an awesome opportunity to deliver a talk in TEDx style, talking to the audience directly instead of hiding behind slides.</p>
<p>My final closing remarks?</p>
<blockquote><p>&#8220;<i>The future is bright. And I want you to promise me something. The next time you think Siri, or Google Voice, or any other NLP toolkit, is being obnoxious, just give it a digital slap on the wrist and hope it will adapt itself and do a better job next time. Try not to get too annoyed or impatient … but instead think about the endless possibilities in which these technologies can make your life easier, acknowledge how well they are already doing on the difficult tasks we have set out for them, and prepare yourself for when they have fully matured. Because I promise you …. It will be mind blowing!</i>&#8220;</p></blockquote>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</section>
</section>

		<script>
			const tl = gsap.timeline({
				scrollTrigger: {
					trigger: "#hero",
					start: "top top",
					end: "bottom top",
					scrub: true
				}
			});

			gsap.utils.toArray(".parallax").forEach(layer => {
				const depth = layer.dataset.depth;
				const movement = -(layer.offsetHeight * depth)
				tl.to(layer, {y: movement, ease: "none"}, 0)
			});
		</script>
		
		<script>
			/* When the user scrolls down, hide the navbar. When the user scrolls up, show the navbar */
			var prevScrollpos = window.pageYOffset;
			window.onscroll = function() {
				var currentScrollPos = window.pageYOffset;								
				
				var x = window.matchMedia("(min-width: 1851px)")
				if(x.matches) {
					if(currentScrollPos > 0) {						
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 0}, 1000);*/

					}
					if(currentScrollPos <= 0) {
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 1}, 1000);*/
					}
				}
				else{
					if(currentScrollPos > 0) {						
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 0}, 1000);*/
					}
					if(currentScrollPos <= 0) {
					/* 	document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 1}, 1000);*/
					}
				}
			
				if(currentScrollPos == "0.0") {
					document.getElementById("nav").style.top = "0.5em";
					<!-- document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = 'auto'; -->
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.borderRadius = '0.8em';
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = "auto";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.width = "40em";
				}
				if (prevScrollpos > currentScrollPos) {
					
				} else {					
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.cssText += 'height:auto;';
					document.getElementById("nav").style.top = "-1.0em";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.borderRadius = '0em';
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = "2.5em";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.width = "100%";					
				}
				prevScrollpos = currentScrollPos;
			}
		</script></footer></main>

<script id="wp-block-template-skip-link-js-after">
	( function() {
		var skipLinkTarget = document.querySelector( 'main' ),
			sibling,
			skipLinkTargetID,
			skipLink;

		// Early exit if a skip-link target can't be located.
		if ( ! skipLinkTarget ) {
			return;
		}

		/*
		 * Get the site wrapper.
		 * The skip-link will be injected in the beginning of it.
		 */
		sibling = document.querySelector( '.wp-site-blocks' );

		// Early exit if the root element was not found.
		if ( ! sibling ) {
			return;
		}

		// Get the skip-link target's ID, and generate one if it doesn't exist.
		skipLinkTargetID = skipLinkTarget.id;
		if ( ! skipLinkTargetID ) {
			skipLinkTargetID = 'wp--skip-link--target';
			skipLinkTarget.id = skipLinkTargetID;
		}

		// Create the skip link.
		skipLink = document.createElement( 'a' );
		skipLink.classList.add( 'skip-link', 'screen-reader-text' );
		skipLink.id = 'wp-skip-link';
		skipLink.href = '#' + skipLinkTargetID;
		skipLink.innerText = 'Skip to content';

		// Inject the skip link.
		sibling.parentElement.insertBefore( skipLink, sibling );
	}() );
	
</script>

e;n.supports.everything||(n.readyCallback(),(e=n.source||{}).concatemoji?t(e.concatemoji):e.wpemoji&&e.twemoji&&(t(e.twemoji),t(e.wpemoji)))}))}((window,document),window._wpemojiSettings);
</script>

<figure class="BlogImageClass wp-block-post-featured-image"><img width="2360" height="1529" src="https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2016_01_15_gellus.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="Table taken from the paper, showcasing the performance of various models." style="object-fit:cover;" decoding="async" fetchpriority="high" srcset="https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2016_01_15_gellus.png 2360w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2016_01_15_gellus-300x194.png 300w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2016_01_15_gellus-1024x663.png 1024w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2016_01_15_gellus-768x498.png 768w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2016_01_15_gellus-1536x995.png 1536w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2016_01_15_gellus-2048x1327.png 2048w" sizes="(max-width: 2360px) 100vw, 2360px" /></figure>

<h2 class="has-text-align-center wp-block-post-title">Cell line name recognition in support of the identification of synthetic lethality in cancer from text</h2></div>


<div class="entry-content BlogTextClass wp-block-post-content has-global-padding is-layout-constrained wp-block-post-content-is-layout-constrained"><h3>Motivation:</h3>
<p>The recognition and normalization of cell line names in text is an important task in biomedical text mining research, facilitating for instance the identification of synthetically lethal genes from the literature. While several tools have previously been developed to address cell line recognition, it is unclear whether available systems can perform sufficiently well in realistic and broad-coverage applications such as extracting synthetically lethal genes from the cancer literature. In this study, we revisit the cell line name recognition task, evaluating both available systems and newly introduced methods on various resources to obtain a reliable tagger not tied to any specific subdomain. In support of this task, we introduce two text collections manually annotated for cell line names: the broad-coverage corpus Gellus and CLL, a focused target domain corpus.</p>
<h3>Results:</h3>
<p>We find that the best performance is achieved using NERsuite, a machine learning system based on Conditional Random Fields, trained on the Gellus corpus and supported with a dictionary of cell line names. The system achieves an F-score of 88.46% on the test set of Gellus and 85.98% on the independently annotated CLL corpus. It was further applied at large scale to 24 302 102 unannotated articles, resulting in the identification of 5 181 342 cell line mentions, normalized to 11 755 unique cell line database identifiers.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><b>→  Paper</b>: <a href="https://academic.oup.com/bioinformatics/article/32/2/276/1744404" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Bioinformatics</a></p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><b>→  Authors</b>: Suwisa Kaewphan, Sofie Van Landeghem, Tomoko Ohta, Yves Van de Peer, Filip Ginter, Sampo Pyysalo</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</section>
</section>

		<script>
			const tl = gsap.timeline({
				scrollTrigger: {
					trigger: "#hero",
					start: "top top",
					end: "bottom top",
					scrub: true
				}
			});

			gsap.utils.toArray(".parallax").forEach(layer => {
				const depth = layer.dataset.depth;
				const movement = -(layer.offsetHeight * depth)
				tl.to(layer, {y: movement, ease: "none"}, 0)
			});
		</script>
		
		<script>
			/* When the user scrolls down, hide the navbar. When the user scrolls up, show the navbar */
			var prevScrollpos = window.pageYOffset;
			window.onscroll = function() {
				var currentScrollPos = window.pageYOffset;								
				
				var x = window.matchMedia("(min-width: 1851px)")
				if(x.matches) {
					if(currentScrollPos > 0) {						
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 0}, 1000);*/

					}
					if(currentScrollPos <= 0) {
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 1}, 1000);*/
					}
				}
				else{
					if(currentScrollPos > 0) {						
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 0}, 1000);*/
					}
					if(currentScrollPos <= 0) {
					/* 	document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 1}, 1000);*/
					}
				}
			
				if(currentScrollPos == "0.0") {
					document.getElementById("nav").style.top = "0.5em";
					<!-- document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = 'auto'; -->
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.borderRadius = '0.8em';
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = "auto";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.width = "40em";
				}
				if (prevScrollpos > currentScrollPos) {
					
				} else {					
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.cssText += 'height:auto;';
					document.getElementById("nav").style.top = "-1.0em";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.borderRadius = '0em';
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = "2.5em";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.width = "100%";					
				}
				prevScrollpos = currentScrollPos;
			}
		</script></footer></main>

<script id="wp-block-template-skip-link-js-after">
	( function() {
		var skipLinkTarget = document.querySelector( 'main' ),
			sibling,
			skipLinkTargetID,
			skipLink;

		// Early exit if a skip-link target can't be located.
		if ( ! skipLinkTarget ) {
			return;
		}

		/*
		 * Get the site wrapper.
		 * The skip-link will be injected in the beginning of it.
		 */
		sibling = document.querySelector( '.wp-site-blocks' );

		// Early exit if the root element was not found.
		if ( ! sibling ) {
			return;
		}

		// Get the skip-link target's ID, and generate one if it doesn't exist.
		skipLinkTargetID = skipLinkTarget.id;
		if ( ! skipLinkTargetID ) {
			skipLinkTargetID = 'wp--skip-link--target';
			skipLinkTarget.id = skipLinkTargetID;
		}

		// Create the skip link.
		skipLink = document.createElement( 'a' );
		skipLink.classList.add( 'skip-link', 'screen-reader-text' );
		skipLink.id = 'wp-skip-link';
		skipLink.href = '#' + skipLinkTargetID;
		skipLink.innerText = 'Skip to content';

		// Inject the skip link.
		sibling.parentElement.insertBefore( skipLink, sibling );
	}() );
	
</script>

<style id='wp-block-post-featured-image-inline-css'>

 <section id="Blog" class="Blog" style="Padding: 0 0 0 0">
<div class="container">															



<main class="wp-block-group is-layout-flow wp-block-group-is-layout-flow">
<div class="wp-block-group has-global-padding is-layout-constrained wp-block-group-is-layout-constrained">
<div style="height:var(--wp--preset--spacing--50)" aria-hidden="true" class="wp-block-spacer"></div>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-full avatarBlog"><img width="145" height="145" src="http://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/Blog.jpg" alt="" class="wp-image-33"/></figure>


<div class="BlogTitleClass wp-block-post-date"><time datetime="2016-01-05T15:10:00+00:00">5 January 2016</time></div>

<figure class="BlogImageClass wp-block-post-featured-image"><img width="2517" height="1615" src="https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2016_01_05_diffany.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="Figure from the paper, showing how differential networks work." style="object-fit:cover;" decoding="async" fetchpriority="high" srcset="https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2016_01_05_diffany.png 2517w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2016_01_05_diffany-300x192.png 300w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2016_01_05_diffany-1024x657.png 1024w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2016_01_05_diffany-768x493.png 768w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2016_01_05_diffany-1536x986.png 1536w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2016_01_05_diffany-2048x1314.png 2048w" sizes="(max-width: 2517px) 100vw, 2517px" /></figure>

<h2 class="has-text-align-center wp-block-post-title">Diffany: an ontology-driven framework to infer, visualise and analyse differential molecular networks</h2></div>


<div class="entry-content BlogTextClass wp-block-post-content has-global-padding is-layout-constrained wp-block-post-content-is-layout-constrained"><h4><b>Background:</b></h4>
<p>Differential networks have recently been introduced as a powerful way to study the dynamic rewiring capabilities of an interactome in response to changing environmental conditions or stimuli. Currently, such differential networks are generated and visualised using ad hoc methods, and are often limited to the analysis of only one condition-specific response or one interaction type at a time.</p>
<h4><b>Results:</b></h4>
<p>In this work, we present a generic, ontology-driven framework to infer, visualise and analyse an arbitrary set of condition-specific responses against one reference network. To this end, we have implemented novel ontology-based algorithms that can process highly heterogeneous networks, accounting for both physical interactions and regulatory associations, symmetric and directed edges, edge weights and negation. We propose this integrative framework as a standardised methodology that allows a unified view on differential networks and promotes comparability between differential network studies. As an illustrative application, we demonstrate its usefulness on a plant abiotic stress study and we experimentally confirmed a predicted regulator.</p>
<p>We made the algorithms available as an open-source package, a commandline interface and a cytoscape plugin.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><b>→  Paper</b>: <a href="https://bmcbioinformatics.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s12859-015-0863-y" target="_blank" rel="noopener">BMC Bioinformatics</a></p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><b>→  Code</b>: <a href="https://github.com/thpar/diffany">Github repo</a></p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><b>→  Authors</b>: Sofie Van Landeghem, Thomas Van Parys, Marieke Dubois, Dirk Inzé, Yves Van de Peer</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</section>
</section>

		<script src="/assets/js/jquery.min.js"></script>
		<script src="/assets/js/jquery.dropotron.min.js"></script>

		<script src="https://s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s.cdpn.io/16327/gsap-latest-beta.min.js?r=5426"></script>
		<script src="https://s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/s.cdpn.io/16327/ScrollTrigger.min.js"></script>
		<script src="https://frogcat.github.io/canvas-arrow/canvas-arrow.js"></script>
		
		<script>
			const tl = gsap.timeline({
				scrollTrigger: {
					trigger: "#hero",
					start: "top top",
					end: "bottom top",
					scrub: true
				}
			});

			gsap.utils.toArray(".parallax").forEach(layer => {
				const depth = layer.dataset.depth;
				const movement = -(layer.offsetHeight * depth)
				tl.to(layer, {y: movement, ease: "none"}, 0)
			});
		</script>
		
		<script>
			/* When the user scrolls down, hide the navbar. When the user scrolls up, show the navbar */
			var prevScrollpos = window.pageYOffset;
			window.onscroll = function() {
				var currentScrollPos = window.pageYOffset;								
				
				var x = window.matchMedia("(min-width: 1851px)")
				if(x.matches) {
					if(currentScrollPos > 0) {						
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 0}, 1000);*/

					}
					if(currentScrollPos <= 0) {
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 1}, 1000);*/
					}
				}
				else{
					if(currentScrollPos > 0) {						
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 0}, 1000);*/
					}
					if(currentScrollPos <= 0) {
					/* 	document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 1}, 1000);*/
					}
				}
			
				if(currentScrollPos == "0.0") {
					document.getElementById("nav").style.top = "0.5em";
					<!-- document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = 'auto'; -->
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.borderRadius = '0.8em';
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = "auto";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.width = "40em";
				}
				if (prevScrollpos > currentScrollPos) {
					
				} else {					
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.cssText += 'height:auto;';
					document.getElementById("nav").style.top = "-1.0em";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.borderRadius = '0em';
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = "2.5em";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.width = "100%";					
				}
				prevScrollpos = currentScrollPos;
			}
		</script></footer></main>
</div>
<script type="speculationrules">
{"prefetch":[{"source":"document","where":{"and":[{"href_matches":"\/*"},{"not":{"href_matches":["\/wp-*.php","\/wp-admin\/*","\/wp-content\/uploads\/*","\/wp-content\/*","\/wp-content\/plugins\/*","\/wp-content\/themes\/twentytwentyfour\/*","\/*\\?(.+)"]}},{"not":{"selector_matches":"a[rel~=\"nofollow\"]"}},{"not":{"selector_matches":".no-prefetch, .no-prefetch a"}}]},"eagerness":"conservative"}]}
</script>
<script id="wp-block-template-skip-link-js-after">
	( function() {
		var skipLinkTarget = document.querySelector( 'main' ),
			sibling,
			skipLinkTargetID,
			skipLink;

		// Early exit if a skip-link target can't be located.
		if ( ! skipLinkTarget ) {
			return;
		}

		/*
		 * Get the site wrapper.
		 * The skip-link will be injected in the beginning of it.
		 */
		sibling = document.querySelector( '.wp-site-blocks' );

		// Early exit if the root element was not found.
		if ( ! sibling ) {
			return;
		}

		// Get the skip-link target's ID, and generate one if it doesn't exist.
		skipLinkTargetID = skipLinkTarget.id;
		if ( ! skipLinkTargetID ) {
			skipLinkTargetID = 'wp--skip-link--target';
			skipLinkTarget.id = skipLinkTargetID;
		}

		// Create the skip link.
		skipLink = document.createElement( 'a' );
		skipLink.classList.add( 'skip-link', 'screen-reader-text' );
		skipLink.id = 'wp-skip-link';
		skipLink.href = '#' + skipLinkTargetID;
		skipLink.innerText = 'Skip to content';

		// Inject the skip link.
		sibling.parentElement.insertBefore( skipLink, sibling );
	}() );
	
</script>
</body>
</html>

			background-color: #eee;
			clip-path: none;

 <section id="Blog" class="Blog" style="Padding: 0 0 0 0">
<div class="container">															



<main class="wp-block-group is-layout-flow wp-block-group-is-layout-flow">
<div class="wp-block-group has-global-padding is-layout-constrained wp-block-group-is-layout-constrained">
<div style="height:var(--wp--preset--spacing--50)" aria-hidden="true" class="wp-block-spacer"></div>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-full avatarBlog"><img width="145" height="145" src="http://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/Blog.jpg" alt="" class="wp-image-33"/></figure>


<div class="BlogTitleClass wp-block-post-date"><time datetime="2015-05-05T16:22:00+00:00">5 May 2015</time></div>

<figure class="BlogImageClass wp-block-post-featured-image"><img width="2482" height="1355" src="https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2015_05_knowtator.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="Screenshot of the Leaf Knowtator annotation framework" style="object-fit:cover;" decoding="async" fetchpriority="high" srcset="https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2015_05_knowtator.png 2482w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2015_05_knowtator-300x164.png 300w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2015_05_knowtator-1024x559.png 1024w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2015_05_knowtator-768x419.png 768w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2015_05_knowtator-1536x839.png 1536w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2015_05_knowtator-2048x1118.png 2048w" sizes="(max-width: 2482px) 100vw, 2482px" /></figure>

<h2 class="has-text-align-center wp-block-post-title">The KnownLeaf literature curation system</h2></div>


<div class="entry-content BlogTextClass wp-block-post-content has-global-padding is-layout-constrained wp-block-post-content-is-layout-constrained"><p>The information that connects genotypes and phenotypes is essentially embedded in research articles written in natural language. To facilitate access to this knowledge, we constructed a framework for the curation of the scientific literature studying the molecular mechanisms that control leaf growth and development in Arabidopsis thaliana (Arabidopsis).</p>
<p>Standard structured statements, called relations, were designed to capture diverse data types, including phenotypes and gene expression linked to genotype description, growth conditions, genetic and molecular interactions, and details about molecular entities. Relations were then annotated from the literature, defining the relevant terms according to standard biomedical ontologies. This curation process was supported by a dedicated graphical user interface, called Leaf Knowtator.</p>
<p>A total of 283 primary research articles were curated by a community of annotators, yielding 9947 relations monitored for consistency and over 12,500 references to Arabidopsis genes. This information was converted into a relational database (KnownLeaf) and merged with other public Arabidopsis resources relative to transcriptional networks, protein–protein interaction, gene co-expression, and additional molecular annotations. Within KnownLeaf, leaf phenotype data can be searched together with molecular data originating either from this curation initiative or from external public resources.</p>
<p>Finally, we built a network (LeafNet) with a portion of the KnownLeaf database content to graphically represent the leaf phenotype relations in a molecular context, offering an intuitive starting point for knowledge mining. Literature curation efforts such as ours provide high quality structured information accessible to computational analysis, and thereby to a wide range of applications.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><b>→  Paper</b>: <a href="https://biblio.ugent.be/publication/5930918" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Current Plant Biology</a></p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><b>→  Authors: </b>Dóra Szakonyi, Sofie Van Landeghem, Katja Baerenfaller, et al.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;">
</div>
</div>
</div>
</section>
</section>

		<script>
			const tl = gsap.timeline({
				scrollTrigger: {
					trigger: "#hero",
					start: "top top",
					end: "bottom top",
					scrub: true
				}
			});

			gsap.utils.toArray(".parallax").forEach(layer => {
				const depth = layer.dataset.depth;
				const movement = -(layer.offsetHeight * depth)
				tl.to(layer, {y: movement, ease: "none"}, 0)
			});
		</script>
		
		<script>
			/* When the user scrolls down, hide the navbar. When the user scrolls up, show the navbar */
			var prevScrollpos = window.pageYOffset;
			window.onscroll = function() {
				var currentScrollPos = window.pageYOffset;								
				
				var x = window.matchMedia("(min-width: 1851px)")
				if(x.matches) {
					if(currentScrollPos > 0) {						
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 0}, 1000);*/

					}
					if(currentScrollPos <= 0) {
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 1}, 1000);*/
					}
				}
				else{
					if(currentScrollPos > 0) {						
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 0}, 1000);*/
					}
					if(currentScrollPos <= 0) {
					/* 	document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 1}, 1000);*/
					}
				}
			
				if(currentScrollPos == "0.0") {
					document.getElementById("nav").style.top = "0.5em";
					<!-- document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = 'auto'; -->
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.borderRadius = '0.8em';
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = "auto";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.width = "40em";
				}
				if (prevScrollpos > currentScrollPos) {
					
				} else {					
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.cssText += 'height:auto;';
					document.getElementById("nav").style.top = "-1.0em";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.borderRadius = '0em';
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = "2.5em";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.width = "100%";					
				}
				prevScrollpos = currentScrollPos;
			}
		</script></footer></main>

<script id="wp-block-template-skip-link-js-after">
	( function() {
		var skipLinkTarget = document.querySelector( 'main' ),
			sibling,
			skipLinkTargetID,
			skipLink;

		// Early exit if a skip-link target can't be located.
		if ( ! skipLinkTarget ) {
			return;
		}

		/*
		 * Get the site wrapper.
		 * The skip-link will be injected in the beginning of it.
		 */
		sibling = document.querySelector( '.wp-site-blocks' );

		// Early exit if the root element was not found.
		if ( ! sibling ) {
			return;
		}

		// Get the skip-link target's ID, and generate one if it doesn't exist.
		skipLinkTargetID = skipLinkTarget.id;
		if ( ! skipLinkTargetID ) {
			skipLinkTargetID = 'wp--skip-link--target';
			skipLinkTarget.id = skipLinkTargetID;
		}

		// Create the skip link.
		skipLink = document.createElement( 'a' );
		skipLink.classList.add( 'skip-link', 'screen-reader-text' );
		skipLink.id = 'wp-skip-link';
		skipLink.href = '#' + skipLinkTargetID;
		skipLink.innerText = 'Skip to content';

		// Inject the skip link.
		sibling.parentElement.insertBefore( skipLink, sibling );
	}() );
	
</script>

<section id="Main" class="main">
 <section id="intro" class="intro">
  <div class="title">Sofie’s Blog</div>
</section>
 <section id="Blog" class="Blog" style="Padding: 0 0 0 0">
<div class="container">															



<main class="wp-block-group is-layout-flow wp-block-group-is-layout-flow">
<div class="wp-block-group has-global-padding is-layout-constrained wp-block-group-is-layout-constrained">
<div style="height:var(--wp--preset--spacing--50)" aria-hidden="true" class="wp-block-spacer"></div>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-full avatarBlog"><img width="145" height="145" src="http://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/Blog.jpg" alt="" class="wp-image-33"/></figure>


<div class="BlogTitleClass wp-block-post-date"><time datetime="2013-08-09T16:30:00+00:00">9 August 2013</time></div>

<figure class="BlogImageClass wp-block-post-featured-image"><img width="3033" height="1000" src="https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2013_08_09_st13.png" class="attachment-post-thumbnail size-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="Table from the paper, showing the performance of our EVEX submission reaching 50.97% F-score" style="object-fit:cover;" decoding="async" fetchpriority="high" srcset="https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2013_08_09_st13.png 3033w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2013_08_09_st13-300x99.png 300w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2013_08_09_st13-1024x338.png 1024w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2013_08_09_st13-768x253.png 768w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2013_08_09_st13-1536x506.png 1536w, https://oxykodit.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/2013_08_09_st13-2048x675.png 2048w" sizes="(max-width: 3033px) 100vw, 3033px" /></figure>

<h2 class="has-text-align-center wp-block-post-title">EVEX in ST’13: Application of a large-scale text mining resource to event extraction and network construction</h2></div>


<div class="entry-content BlogTextClass wp-block-post-content has-global-padding is-layout-constrained wp-block-post-content-is-layout-constrained"><h3>Background:</h3>
<p>Modern methods for mining biomolecular interactions from literature typically make predictions based solely on the immediate textual context, in effect a single sentence. No prior work has been published on extending this context to the information automatically gathered from the whole biomedical literature. Thus, our motivation for this study is to explore whether mutually supporting evidence, aggregated across several documents can be utilized to improve the performance of the state-of-the-art event extraction systems.</p>
<p>In this paper, we describe our participation in the latest BioNLP Shared Task using the large-scale text mining resource EVEX. We participated in the Genia Event Extraction (GE) and Gene Regulation Network (GRN) tasks with two separate systems. In the GE task, we implemented a re-ranking approach to improve the precision of an existing event extraction system, incorporating features from the EVEX resource. In the GRN task, our system relied solely on the EVEX resource and utilized a rule-based conversion algorithm between the EVEX and GRN formats.</p>
<h3>Results:</h3>
<p>In the GE task, our re-ranking approach led to a modest performance increase and resulted in the first rank of the official Shared Task results with 50.97% F-score. Additionally, in this paper we explore and evaluate the usage of distributed vector representations for this challenge.</p>
<p>In the GRN task, we ranked fifth in the official results with a strict/relaxed SER score of 0.92/0.81 respectively. To try and improve upon these results, we have implemented a novel machine learning based conversion system and benchmarked its performance against the original rule-based system.</p>
<h3>Conclusions:</h3>
<p>For the GRN task, we were able to produce a gene regulatory network from the EVEX data, warranting the use of such generic large-scale text mining data in network biology settings. A detailed performance and error analysis provides more insight into the relatively low recall rates.</p>
<p>In the GE task we demonstrate that both the re-ranking approach and the word vectors can provide slight performance improvement. A manual evaluation of the re-ranking results pinpoints some of the challenges faced in applying large-scale text mining knowledge to event extraction.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><b>→  Papers</b>: <a href="https://aclanthology.org/W13-2004/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">BioNLP proceedings</a> and <a href="https://bmcbioinformatics.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/1471-2105-16-S16-S3" target="_blank" rel="noopener">BMC Bioinformatics</a></p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><b>→  Authors</b>: Kai Hakala, Sofie Van Landeghem, Tapio Salakoski, Yves Van de Peer, Filip Ginter</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</section>
</section>

		<script>
			const tl = gsap.timeline({
				scrollTrigger: {
					trigger: "#hero",
					start: "top top",
					end: "bottom top",
					scrub: true
				}
			});

			gsap.utils.toArray(".parallax").forEach(layer => {
				const depth = layer.dataset.depth;
				const movement = -(layer.offsetHeight * depth)
				tl.to(layer, {y: movement, ease: "none"}, 0)
			});
		</script>
		
		<script>
			/* When the user scrolls down, hide the navbar. When the user scrolls up, show the navbar */
			var prevScrollpos = window.pageYOffset;
			window.onscroll = function() {
				var currentScrollPos = window.pageYOffset;								
				
				var x = window.matchMedia("(min-width: 1851px)")
				if(x.matches) {
					if(currentScrollPos > 0) {						
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 0}, 1000);*/

					}
					if(currentScrollPos <= 0) {
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 1}, 1000);*/
					}
				}
				else{
					if(currentScrollPos > 0) {						
						/* document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 0}, 1000);*/
					}
					if(currentScrollPos <= 0) {
					/* 	document.getElementById("HeaderIntro").animate({opacity: 1}, 1000);*/
					}
				}
			
				if(currentScrollPos == "0.0") {
					document.getElementById("nav").style.top = "0.5em";
					<!-- document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = 'auto'; -->
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.borderRadius = '0.8em';
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = "auto";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.width = "40em";
				}
				if (prevScrollpos > currentScrollPos) {
					
				} else {					
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.cssText += 'height:auto;';
					document.getElementById("nav").style.top = "-1.0em";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.borderRadius = '0em';
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.height = "2.5em";
					document.getElementById("nav").children[0].style.width = "100%";					
				}
				prevScrollpos = currentScrollPos;
			}
		</script></footer></main>

{"prefetch":[{"source":"document","where":{"and":[{"href_matches":"\/*"},{"not":{"href_matches":["\/wp-*.php","\/wp-admin\/*","\/wp-content\/uploads\/*","\/wp-content\/*","\/wp-content\/plugins\/*","\/wp-content\/themes\/twentytwentyfour\/*","\/*\\?(.+)"]}},{"not":{"selector_matches":"a[rel~=\"nofollow\"]"}},{"not":{"selector_matches":".no-prefetch, .no-prefetch a"}}]},"eagerness":"conservative"}]}
